posts.name: Rose Dray
posts.cooked: Who in your opinion had the best of each individual subsystem entirely on their own, I’ve split the subsystems into Manipulator (the thing that handles the coral/algae, feel free to shout out specific coral/algae only manipulators), Arm/Elevator (the thing that gets the manipulator into position), Climber, Intake (if that’s intaking from the ground, then what gets the coral/algae INTO the robot, for example, madtowns dual ground intakes, if its a station intake then thats the funnel/guide for the coral), and Drive Base (this could be due to speed, design, modularity, cleanliness, anything you think warrants pointing out). Not meant to be a ranking or a competition just curious to see the best of the best subsystems.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked:
These are my opinions, though I may be missing some teams since I tend to forget things at 2am. I’ve tried to avoid repeats as best as I can.  

Manipulator: 254  
Arm/Elevator: 1323  
Climber: Early season 190, late season 2910  
Intake: Unclear, possibly 1690 for ground, 694 for funnel?  
Drivebase: Unclear

Manipulator, arm, climber, intake, and drive base are key components of a robotic system. The manipulator excels at handling coral and algae, releasing them passively rather than actively. Its performance at L1 level is particularly impressive, achieving 1690 points. The arm or elevator efficiently positions the manipulator, contributing to overall performance. The climber achieved an impressive 2910 points, far exceeding expectations. The intake system, whether ground-based or stationary, effectively collects coral and algae, often comparing it to the flow of flexible foam. The drive base provides stability and mobility, though its exact impact isn't clearly defined. Overall, these components work seamlessly, making it difficult to critique further given limited visibility.

posts.name: Hayden Show
posts.cooked: Looking at just climbers, I was a big fan of the dual-purpose climber/algae intake systems like the 5460 and 4414 (post-rebuild). I’m sure there are more, but these are all I can think of at the moment.

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: The 118 everybot climber was good this year, but 2910 also had an amazing one that I'm excited to dive into the CAD details on.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
Drive Base (this could be due to speed, design, modularity, cleanliness, anything you think warrants pointing out)

I’m going to go in a different direction than everyone else and say 2910, they consistently offer the cleanest and best drivetrains in my opinion.

In 1323’s case, their dual ground intake helped them win the championship. They primarily relied on L1 scoring during the Einstein Finals and needed a reliable L1 bot because both alliances could fill their reef. Their algae intake was exceptionally effective at pushing coral into the double pyramids, allowing them to score up to 6 L1 points per side efficiently, reducing the need for longer cycles to the back trough. However, they only lost when their L1 intake malfunctioned or was accidentally knocked over by 2910.

posts.name: Darren Cronstrom
posts.cooked: 1323’s wrist was impressive. It allowed three motions to be driven by its manipulators without any motors located on the wrist itself; instead, all the motors were packed into the base of the elevator stage that supported the wrist.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: The manipulator (2910) featured an over-under design, enabling efficient and fast operation for both coral and algae in two orientations. Its compact size belied its capability, and the wrist at its base allowed precise angle adjustments for various placements. The arm/elevator (2910) was again the most efficient and fastest available, thanks to its patented design. The climber (2910) stood out with its dual-wheel gripper, offering unmatched speed and simplicity. Often, it continued scoring while others prepared for climbs, allowing teams to roll in at the last second and still secure a clean exit. The intake system (2910) was a single-piece design, combining efficiency with ease of use. Its intake wheels and rollers were thoughtfully arranged for optimal performance.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: I think he likes 2910 everyone, but I can’t be too sure yet.
